elements.text: Thanks for all the tips everyone! Going to try a few of these out

text: I think it really depends on the audience you're trying to reach and if those segments have interest in the same topic. I've tried both niching down and creating 6+ webinars a month on specific topics for each audience segment, and I've also tried holding 1-2 "anchor" webinars with a lot more promotion involved - with mixed results. I'm now planning on a hybrid of this for next quarter - month 1 holding one major webinar, then months 2 and 3 getting more specific based on questions we gather from month 1's. No right or wrong answer! But it's more about your audience and your goal vs. the number.

elements.text: I think it really depends on the audience you're trying to reach and if those segments have interest in the same topic. I've tried both niching down and creating 6+ webinars a month on specific topics for each audience segment, and I've also tried holding 1-2 "anchor" webinars with a lot more promotion involved - with mixed results. I'm now planning on a hybrid of this for next quarter - month 1 holding one major webinar, then months 2 and 3 getting more specific based on questions we gather from month 1's. No right or wrong answer! But it's more about your audience and your goal vs. the number.

text: Would anyone be up for doing newsletter swaps with 360Learning? Our English-speaking email list is around 50K, mostly HR and Learning & development leaders but also sales enablement/sales training professionals. If you have a newsletter of similar size with a similar audience, we can do a one-off thing to try (swap an ebook/webinar/or blog article) and if it works well make it a regular thing. We’ve done newsletter swaps with partners like Pandadoc, Toggl, Chartmogul, ExecVision, Venngage, GoCo, <http://Reply.io|Reply.io>, HR Partner, etc. Topics of content could be anything related to productivity, remote work, HR, onboarding, training, learning, team management, etc.

text: I highly recommend Jon Acampora’s Excel Campus <https://m.youtube.com/user/ExcelCampus|https://m.youtube.com/user/ExcelCampus> and he sometimes holds pivot table webinars <https://www.excelcampus.com|https://www.excelcampus.com>  his online pivot table course is called Pivot Ready

attachments.title: Excel Campus - Jon
attachments.text: Excel Campus is here to help you learn Excel and save you time with your everyday tasks. My name is Jon Acampora and my goal is to help you improve your Excel skills. This channel contains "how-to" tutorial style videos on a wide range of Excel topics including: formulas, pivot tables, macros, VBA, charts, dashboards, Power Query, Power Pivot, Power BI, and much more. I want to hear from you and learn about what you are struggling with in Excel. Please visit my website and subscribe to my free email newsletter. <http://www.excelcampus.com/newsletter/> And don't forget to subscribe to our YouTube channel. Thank you!

text: Haven't been able to test much. The blog is brand new, but I see it as offering more value to the reader and getting their attention. None of it is gated in this instance. Just an article and the info listed.

text: Speaking to personal experience, I've run probably 50+ headline tests over the past couple years when a product was being sold/given away, and the HubSpot promoted [Free Template] style hasn't made a consistent statistical impact on any of them ... EXCEPT when we have bracketed [Quiz]. A natural inclusion of the asset has outperformed the bracketed version at least 50 percent of the time, so we always test multiple headlines for an article and go with the one that has a statistical advantage after a set period of time. Sometimes it's the bracketed version, sometimes it's the natural inclusion. Only way to know is with an A/B test.

elements.text: Speaking to personal experience, I've run probably 50+ headline tests over the past couple years when a product was being sold/given away, and the HubSpot promoted [Free Template] style hasn't made a consistent statistical impact on any of them ... EXCEPT when we have bracketed [Quiz]. A natural inclusion of the asset has outperformed the bracketed version at least 50 percent of the time, so we always test multiple headlines for an article and go with the one that has a statistical advantage after a set period of time. Sometimes it's the bracketed version, sometimes it's the natural inclusion. Only way to know is with an A/B test.

text: One more recommendation- Leila Gharani. I’ve watched a few of her YouTube videos and found them helpful <https://m.youtube.com/channel/UCJtUOos_MwJa_Ewii-R3cJA|https://m.youtube.com/channel/UCJtUOos_MwJa_Ewii-R3cJA>

attachments.title: Leila Gharani
attachments.text: Welcome! It's great to have you here! I share videos related to Office Productivity. My goal is to help you save time so you can spend it on the activities that matter. I create videos on: - Microsoft Excel, PowerPoint, VBA, OneNote and other Office Products - Google Sheets - Accounting & Finance I love to learn new tools and techniques and share these will you. I hope to inspire you to experiment and share with others. My background: MA in economics / Economist / Business Consultant / Accounting Systems Expert / Oracle & SAP implementations (for Finance) / Teacher & Microsoft MVP Subscribe if you'd like to improve your skills. New video every Thursday - with frequent bonus videos on Tuesdays. Don't forget to get my free top 10 formulas e-book from <https://www.xelplus.com/free-ebook/> ➹ ➹ My Online Excel Courses ➹ ➹ The complete list of my courses: <https://www.xelplus.com/courses/> Let’s connect on Instagram: <https://www.instagram.com/lgharani>
